SENT.plain: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) has a poor prognosis due to treatment-resistant relapses
A humanized anti-CD33 antibody (Mylotarg) showed a limited response rate in relapsed AML
To discover novel AML antibody targets, we selected a panel of single chain Fv fragments using phage display technology combined with flow cytometry on AML tumor samples
One selected single chain Fv fragment broadly reacted with AML samples and with myeloid cell lineages within peripheral blood
Expression cloning identified the antigen recognized as C-type lectin-like molecule-1 (CLL-1), a previously undescribed transmembrane glycoprotein
CLL-1 expression was analyzed with a human anti-CLL-1 antibody that was generated from the single chain Fv fragment
CLL-1 is restricted to the hematopoietic lineage, in particular to myeloid cells present in peripheral blood and bone marrow
CLL-1 is absent on uncommitted CD34(+)/CD38(-) or CD34(+)/CD33(-) stem cells and present on subsets of CD34(+)/CD38(+) or CD34(+)/CD33(+) progenitor cells
CLL-1 is not expressed in any other tissue
In contrast, analysis of primary AMLs demonstrated CLL-1 expression in 92% (68 of 74) of the samples
As an AML marker, CLL-1 was able to complement CD33, because 67% (8 of 12) of the CD33(-) AMLs expressed CLL-1
CLL-1 showed variable expression (10-60%) in CD34(+) cells in chronic myelogenous leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome but was absent in 12 of 13 cases of acute lymphoblastic leukemia
The AML reactivity combined with the restricted expression on normal cells identifies CLL-1 as a novel potential target for AML treatment
